Wardle announced he would not contest the 2001 election in early 2000 after it was disclosed that he was doing consultancy for [[Mohammed Al-Fayed]].<ref name=faction>{{cite news| url = http://www.guardian.co.uk/politics/2000/apr/10/uk.thatcher | title = Nasty Tory faction led me to quit, says MP who took Harrods job | accessdate = 2010-01-27 | date = 2000-04-10 | publisher = ''[[The Guardian]]'' | location=London | first=Nicholas | last=Watt}}</ref> He was replaced by [[Gregory Barker]] in the [[United Kingdom general election, 2001|2001 General Election]]. He supported the [[United Kingdom Independence Party]]'s (UKIP) [[Nigel Farage]] in that election to replace him. ==Education== Wardle was educated at [[Tonbridge School]],<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/special/politics97/mps/897.shtml BBC Politics '97 - Charles Wardle] Publisher: ''[[BBC News]]''. Retrieved: 4 January, 2013.</ref> a boarding [[independent school]] in the [[market town]] of [[Tonbridge]] in [[Kent]] in [[South East England]], where he boarded at School House,<ref>[http://www.oldtonbridgians.org/h/n/OTS/news/ALL/152/ October 2005 Reunion] Publisher: ''Old Tonbridgian Society'' of ''[[Tonbridge School]]''. Retrieved: 4 January, 2013.</ref> followed by [[Lincoln College, Oxford|Lincoln College]] at the [[University of Oxford]] in the city of [[Oxford]] and [[Harvard Business School]], the graduate business school of [[Harvard University]], in the city of [[Boston, Massachusetts|Boston]] in [[Massachusetts]], in the United States.<ref>[http://www.guardian.co.uk/politics/person/5398/charles-wardle Charles Wardle: Electoral history and profile] Publisher: ''[[The Guardian]]'' online. Retrieved: 4 January, 2013.</ref> ==Life and career== In the Conservative government, Wardle had been an immigration minister under the then-[[Home Secretary]], [[Michael Howard]].<ref name=ratchets>{{cite news| url = http://www.guardian.co.uk/society/2005/apr/11/asylum.immigrationasylumandrefugees | title = Howard ratchets up immigration rhetoric | accessdate = 2010-01-27 | date = 2005-04-11 | publisher = ''[[The Guardian]]'' | location=London | first=Patrick | last=Barkham}}</ref> In the [[United Kingdom general election, 2005|2005 general election]], he appeared with the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] to denounce his former boss's plans on immigration and to endorse Labour.<ref name=ratchets/> ==References== {{reflist}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME =Wardle, Charles | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = British politician | DATE OF BIRTH =1939-08-23 | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Wardle, Charles}} [[Category:1939 births]] [[Category:Alumni of Lincoln College, Oxford]] [[Category:Conservative Party (UK) MPs]] [[Category:Harvard Business School alumni]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Members of the United Kingdom Parliament for English constituencies]] [[Category:People educated at Tonbridge School]] [[Category:UK MPs 1983–1987]] [[Category:UK MPs 1987–1992]] [[Category:UK MPs 1992–1997]] [[Category:UK MPs 1997–2001]] {{Conservative-UK-MP-1930s-stub}}
